Award.AwardTitle: Using Web-based Video Peer-Feedback to Support the Diffusion and Enhancement of Teaching Practices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Video-Annotated Peer Review (VAPR) project addresses a growing need to support the diffusion of research-based instructional practices and to create a formative feedback process to enhance faculty development. The project is developing an asynchronous video-based peer feedback system using commercially available software to record faculty in their practice. A network of faculty members review the videos using an instrument developed to facilitate feedback. The software allows faculty peer reviewers to annotate the video with time-stamped comments, thus enabling participating faculty and their peers to identify specific instances of good practices, opportunities for improvement, and opportunities where research-based teaching approaches can be included in their classroom.

VAPR is creating an approach to faculty peer evaluation that supports the diffusion of research-based instructional practices that can be used to supplement or support student evaluations of instruction, and support student learning. This activity advances the knowledge of learning communities within the context of higher education and faculty development by integrating it with the use of educational technology and social reflexivity's support of diffusion. The evaluation and research projects are yielding findings related to the impact that peer feedback has on student learning through direct assessments used for program accreditation, general education assessments, student end-of-term evaluations, and a measure of the rate of diffusion of research-based instructional practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While there have been advances in the knowledge associated with effective instruction in Science, Technology, and Engineering courses, the adoption of these evidence-based instructional practices (EBIPs) and diffusion across courses and contexts have lagged. Integrating educational technology and teaching observations, this study developed and assessed the impact of a Video-Annotated Peer Review (VAPR) process to encourage the adoption of EBIPs by a cohort of twelve engineering educators who predominately teach first-year engineering course at a medium sized private institution. The assessment of outcomes and research activities focused on answering the question: How does participation in a faculty learning communities, established through video annotated peer review, impact the adoption of evidence-based instructional practices?

Utilizing a commercially available software (e.g. Swivl), the developed process requires the faculty member who is the object of review to video record and write a reflection on a class session. That video is then consecutively reviewed by a teaching and learning expert (TLE) and two peers. During their review the TLE can provide contextualized comments at specific timestamps in the video noting observed implementations of EBIPs or opportunities for their use. The peer reviewers are then able to add their own comments in addition to seeing the TLE’s annotations. After the reviews are complete, the object of review reviews the comments from the TLE and their peers and completes a post-review written reflection using the same software.

 

The VAPR process was implemented in the cohort over a four-year period. Utilizing a case study design, the outcomes of the study assessed implementation and diffusion of EBIPs, changes in general approaches to teaching, changes in student satisfaction and student engagement. At the start of the study, all of the faculty used some approach to active learning at varying frequency. By the end of the study, low active learning users implemented it during a larger portion of class time and high active learning users maintained their use. The cohort as a whole increased their use of several EBIPs including think-pair-share, collaborative and cooperative learning, and inquiry learning. These outcomes were not universal among the cohort and more common among faculty who were classified as “adopters” who readily made changes to their instruction and “persisters” who continuously revised their current implementation. Faculty who were identified as “maintainers” continued their use of evidence-based instruction with little change and did not seek new opportunities to implement feedback they received in the course and “resisters” actively rejected the feedback they received in the VAPR process. Beyond the inclusion of more active learning there were no prominent changes in student engagement or student satisfaction beyond fewer critical comments on instruction in the open-response portion of the end-of course evaluation.

When examining specifically how faculty level of concern and level of use of EBIPs changes as a result of participation in a faculty learning community using VAPR, it was observed that faculty moved their concern from a self-focused perspective towards more task-oriented and in some cased impact focus. In the interviews faculty noted when using VAPR they found themselves asking “is this something I could use” and “how are the students responding to the instruction”. While this was the general trend for most of the EBIPs examined, VAPR was seen to propagate misconceptions associated with lesser known evidence-based instruction, such as just-in-time teaching, and those with high starting misconceptions such as problem-based learning. While the use of several EBIPs increased, there was little movement on the level of use with the cohort focusing more on making the practice a routine component of their instruction with few faculty focusing on refinement or integrating across other courses.

Additional research examined the role that professional demographics and the role the TLE had on the type of feedback provided. Overall, familiarity with a course led to more comments associated with specific teaching techniques related to the content, whereas the TLE and those not familiar with the course made more comments on general pedagogy. The TLE was also found to be critical in the identification of EBIPs. When the TLE was not involved, there were very few comments regarding evidence-based instruction and several of those made by the faculty participants propagated misconceptions about a specific EBIP. These findings supported the need for subject matter experts and teaching and learning experts in order to effectively support the adoption of EBIPs when implementing VAPR.

Overall, this work has been disseminated in conference papers, workshops at national conferences, and the creation of a website (https://www.vaprcommunity.net/) to ensure open access to the resources needed to implement VAPR by other institutions. Institutionally, the approach has been adopted by the engineering department in the study, a smaller cohort of faculty at another university, and by the local faculty development training center as part of their faculty development programming for the 2017/2018 academic year.
